text:
The reason people have such a respect for this theme...

 Imagine. A child, stumbling through the Dark Tunnel. You have experienced the knockouts of your pokemon countless times, for you forgot the HM. When you finally found it, you walked through, still scared from the enormity of it. Barely getting through, you finally get through. Happy to hear the Route music again, you went through...
Continue

author: King1N

text: When the game was first released in Japan, there was an odd phenomenon between children ages 7-12, particularly in those using headphones to listen to the sound effects. Increase of nosebleeds, irritability, insomnia, and addiction to the game, playing for hours and hours on end and crying to the point of vomitting when the opportunity was taken away. 70% of these cases ended in suicide.
author: kamfrass

text: In almost every case, despite game time hours recorded to the limit of the internal clock, the game had not progressed further than "Lavender Town".
author: kamfrass

text: A closer analysis of the game revealed a pitch of sound in the audio of the music for "Lavender Town" undetectable by fully developed human ear drums. Thousands of these "first edition" copies of the game (which conatin some other small differences) were recalled and the game was rereleased with remastered audio for "Lavender Town".
author: kamfrass

text: The widely known version is said to be missing three extra notes, as well as the unique, binural pitch of the first edition, although this is uncomfirmed due to the rarity of working first edition copies; the internal clock and 'battery save' have all timed out and ceased fucntion, and in many cases the game will freeze upon entering any battle.
author: kamfrass

text: Well, it used to be rock paper scissors back then. Now that you say that, I'd prefer back then.
author: ZhadoxFlamez

text: the main type which pissed me off was the ghost type... in red/silver, they had very unorthodox attacks... moves that were creepy, and slowly wore down on the enemie's health, or dragged them down with you if you were defeated. they werent DIRECTLY powerful, as they had no real one-turn "flamethrower" type attacks... with this, they were tougher to defeat, given their type... now, pretty much evey pokemon can learn dark type, and even ghost type moves to defeat them easily.
author: Thraxxacor

text: Uh... no... actually, I mean the exact opposite... The game used to be hard... luck played a larger role, and type had a much bigger impact. pokemon had more limited movesets, and there was little to no hope of defeating an opponenet with a type advantage over you. now, every type can learn a huge variety of moves that may or may not make sense regarding the pokemon's type, and defeat just about any opponent as long as youve got a few levels on them.
author: Thraxxacor

text: yeah.... in the old days you just beat at each other hoping luck was on your side.
